text: In which city was the ancient Colosseum built?
Which empire built a long wall in northern China now known as the Great Wall?
Which famous ship sank in 1912 on its first voyage after hitting an iceberg?
Who is often called the "Maid of Orléans" for her role in the Hundred Years' War?
Which ancient civilization built the pyramids at Giza?
The city of Machu Picchu is linked to which civilization?
Which famous scientist formulated the theory of relativity?
Which revolution in the late 18th century led to the fall of the monarchy in France?
Which ancient city was destroyed by a volcanic eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 CE?
Which conflict was later called World War I?
The Silk Road mainly connected Europe with which broad region?
Which 15th-century invention in Europe greatly increased the spread of printed books?
The "Black Death" that struck Europe in the 14th century was mainly which disease?
Which leader carried out large military campaigns across Europe in the early 19th century?
Which early civilization developed in the region between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers?
Which event in 1929 triggered a worldwide economic crisis often called the Great Depression?
options: Stock market crash in New York

text: Which African country resisted full European colonization and won the Battle of Adwa in 1896?
Which 20th-century conflict is strongly associated with trench warfare on the Western Front?
Which ancient code of laws is associated with a Babylonian ruler and the phrase "an eye for an eye"?
Which empire was ruled for centuries from the city of Constantinople (now Istanbul)?
Which 14th-century pandemic killed millions of people across Europe and is known as the Black Death?
The Hundred Years’ War was primarily fought between which two kingdoms?
Which event in 1789 is commonly taken as the beginning of the French Revolution?
Which king of the Franks was crowned Emperor of the Romans in 800 CE?
Which treaty signed in 1648 is often said to have established the modern system of European sovereign states?
Which powerful maritime republic was a major trading hub in the Mediterranean and Adriatic during the late Middle Ages and Renaissance?
Which Portuguese explorer was the first European to reach India by sea around Africa?
Which 1588 naval defeat marked the decline of Spanish sea power and a rise in English influence?
Which 16th-century religious movement split Western Christianity and led to the rise of Protestant churches?
Which German monk is associated with the Ninety-Five Theses and criticism of indulgences in 1517?
Which war from 1618 to 1648 devastated much of Central Europe and ended with the Peace of Westphalia?
Which 18th-century intellectual movement emphasized reason, science, and individual rights in Europe?
Which military leader became Emperor of the French and led major campaigns across Europe in the early 19th century?
Which 1815 meeting of the great powers attempted to restore order in Europe after the Napoleonic Wars?
Which 19th-century statesman is known as the “Iron Chancellor” and key architect of German unification?
Which kingdom played the leading role in the political unification of Italy in the 19th century?
Whose assassination in Sarajevo in 1914 triggered the diplomatic crisis that led to World War I?
Which alliance did Germany, Austria-Hungary, and the Ottoman Empire belong to during World War I?
Which 1919 treaty formally ended the war between Germany and the Allied Powers after World War I?
Which Italian leader founded a fascist regime and ruled his country as a dictator in the interwar period?
In which year did Germany invade Poland, starting World War II in Europe?
What name is given to the Allied landings in Normandy in June 1944?
Which term did Winston Churchill popularize to describe the division of Europe into Western and Soviet spheres after World War II?
Which 1948–1949 crisis saw land routes to West Berlin blocked and supplies flown in by air?
The Treaty of Rome of 1957 created a community that became a forerunner of which modern organization?
In which country did the Solidarity trade union become a major force in ending communist rule in the 1980s?
Which multinational state in southeastern Europe broke up in the 1990s into republics such as Croatia, Slovenia, and Serbia?
Which 1998 agreement helped bring an end to most of the violence in Northern Ireland?
Which country voted in a 2016 referendum to leave the European Union?
Which 1555 agreement in the Holy Roman Empire allowed each prince to choose between Lutheranism and Catholicism for his territory?
Which 1598 decree granted limited toleration to French Protestants (Huguenots) before being revoked by Louis XIV in 1685?
Which economic policy, associated with Jean-Baptiste Colbert under Louis XIV, emphasized state regulation and accumulation of bullion through a favorable balance of trade?
Which 1701–1714 conflict arose over who would inherit the Spanish throne after the death of the childless Charles II of Spain?
Which 18th-century pan-European conflict has been called the first 'world war' due to its fighting in Europe, North America, and Asia?
Which Enlightenment thinker’s concept of separation of powers heavily influenced later constitutional systems in Europe and the Americas?
Which 19th-century diplomatic system sought to maintain the balance of power through periodic conferences among the great powers after 1815?
Which late-19th-century alliance network, designed by Bismarck to isolate France diplomatically, included Germany, Austria-Hungary, and initially Italy?
Which 1951 treaty created a joint authority to manage coal and steel production among six Western European states as a step toward integration?
Which 1992 treaty transformed the European Communities into the European Union and introduced the framework for a common currency?
